posts.name: Tom
posts.cooked: Hello everyone, I want some of my subteam projects to focus on creating software tools that will help the FRC community, do you have any tools you would like to use?

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked: Print one field layout, laminate it, use whiteboard markers to draw on the laminated surface, take a photo when done, save it securely, erase the markings, and reuse. You’ll have the rest of the season to focus on developing other tools or helping with WPILib.

posts.name: Mr. Siefen | 453
posts.cooked: The size of screens can limit their utility, especially when trying to view large images or maps without zooming in too close. For instance, you can't examine a vast area in one go unless you bring your own desktop monitor. Meanwhile, tools like clipboards are handy for quick reference during matches. Some people carry very large ones, such as the one shown here, which is 8 units in size—helpful for detailed planning before the game. The image depicts a "giant clipboard" measuring 500×750 pixels and weighing approximately 60 kilobytes.

I'm co-developing an app designed to assist FIRST Robotics Competition (FRC) teams both on and off the field with the exact tools you're describing. This includes features like whiteboard functionality, a team scouting list generator, and an accessible match table. Additionally, we're developing a live match scouting interface. For more information, visit our GitHub repository at github.com/Skac121245/Robort.

posts.name: Amit sucher
posts.cooked: I was looking at the strat canvas, it looks really cool, and I might steal some features—the API to get the team is a genius idea, although it takes time to write the six teams and it always looks bad. Different colors could help teams know their paths better. Additionally, I noticed that when switching tabs, teams suddenly disappear, which might be annoying, but having them appear on both match phases sounds like a good improvement.
Thank you for the feedback. We'll definitely add the colors to our priorities and have been working on resolving the switching tabs issue for some time, hoping it will be sorted soon.

posts.name: Amit sucher
posts.cooked: When adding the teams, how do you assign their positions using XY coordinates? The issue I'm having is that it works on my PC but looks strange on my laptop.
I'll reach out to my development partner and reply back. I wasn't very involved with the strategic board when creating the app.

posts.name: Amit sucher
posts.cooked: I fixed that, but I’d still love to hear how you did it. The way I did it was by calculating the screen size, specifically using the standard 1920x1080 resolution. I divided the desired width by the regular width to determine the ratio, which I then applied to where I wanted to place the teams’ numbers.

posts.name: Ben Skraly
posts.cooked:
Wow, that’s much smarter than what we did... BTW I’m the other co-dev of Robot. Anyway, this project just turned into something great as we learned how to work in these environments (like JavaScript, Bootstrap, Electron). I took a very straightforward approach (explained later) and created a window outside the canvas and image area to serve as a landing page for displaying numbers and boxes. Using XY coordinates allowed me to place them exactly where I wanted. This setup also makes it future-proof because all I need to do is update the coordinates and refresh the image, and it’ll be ready.

Additionally, existing feature requests mentioned earlier are already addressed. You can toggle the drawing color by selecting each team’s number, which will display color bars on either side of the field to indicate the player’s color. However, teams aren’t showing up in the next tab, which is a known issue we’re working on. To resolve it, you can reset the settings by either reselecting the match from the API or manually inputting it after switching tabs. Teams will then populate automatically, and they’ll save correctly for both sides without any additional issues.

posts.name: Amit sucher
posts.cooked: Choosing the color of the brush based on a team is really cool! Thanks for the idea 😊
